perturbation.original_text: Oceanic Time Warner Cable will include the following disclaimer on the Watchit Content: “The materials shown are for entertainment purposes only and does not provide any guarantees of winning or improving your odds of winning on this program. The rules of the games as shown may not apply to all properties and may change from time to time.”
perturbation.changed_text: Oceanic Time Warner Cable may, at its discretion, include a disclaimer on the Watchit Content.
perturbation.explanation: This change removes the mandatory disclaimer about the content being for entertainment purposes only and not guaranteeing wins. Given that the content involves gaming guides and potentially gambling-related content shown on a Las Vegas channel, omitting this disclaimer could be seen as misleading advertising, especially if viewers are led to believe the content guarantees success. This is a legal risk, as it violates truth-in-advertising laws designed to protect consumers from deceptive or misleading claims, particularly prevalent in the gaming and gambling industries.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Nevada Deceptive Trade Practices Act (NRS 598.090 – 598.0999) and Federal Trade Commission (FTC) advertising guidelines regarding endorsements and testimonials.

perturbation.original_text: Watchit shall have the exclusive right to sell third party advertising as sponsors of their content and will have the right to brand the content under the Watchit brand and place a “bug” on the screen identifying the content with a Watchit trademark.
perturbation.changed_text: Watchit will have the right to brand the content under the Watchit brand.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of Watchit's exclusive right to sell third-party advertising creates potential conflicts of interest and could violate advertising disclosure laws. If Watchit brands the content but Oceanic Time Warner Cable also sells advertising, viewers might not be able to distinguish between Watchit's sponsored content and other advertising. This omission could lead to a lack of transparency regarding who is responsible for the advertising claims, violating advertising regulations that require clear disclosure of sponsors and paid endorsements, particularly relevant in the media and entertainment industry.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Trade Commission (FTC) advertising guidelines regarding clear and conspicuous disclosure of advertising.

perturbation.original_text: Ocean Time Warner Cable will provide Watchit with data on viewership to both Channel 777 and specifically to the content provided by Watchit.
perturbation.changed_text: Ocean Time Warner Cable may provide Watchit with data on viewership to Channel 777.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'will' to 'may' and removing the specific obligation to provide viewership data related to Watchit's content, this modification eliminates a crucial element for Watchit to assess the effectiveness of its content and advertising. In the absence of guaranteed viewership data, Watchit cannot accurately assess the value of the content and may be unable to demonstrate its effectiveness to potential advertisers. This lack of information could constitute a breach of implied warranty of merchantability because Watchit cannot assess the business impacts of providing the content.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied warranty of merchantability, and general contract law regarding 'good faith and fair dealing' in performance.
